tools.name: search
tools.description: Search the web for high-quality content including research papers, technical documentation, news articles, code repositories, and authoritative websites. Returns full content with AI-generated summaries and metadata. Supports category filtering for targeted results (github, news, research papers, pdf, tweets, etc). Best for finding specific types of content, recent information, or results from trusted sources. Note: For searching professionals/candidates/people, use people_search tool; for searching companies/organizations, use company_search tool.

parameters.name: query
parameters.description: Search query in natural language. Be specific and clear about what you're looking for.
examples: how to implement server-side rendering in Next.js 15

parameters.name: numResults
parameters.description: Number of results to return. Default: 5, Max: 10
parameters.note: 代码执行时会被限制为最大 10

parameters.name: category
parameters.description: Content category filter for higher quality, targeted results

parameters.name: searchType
parameters.description: Search algorithm mode: 'auto' (recommended, balances quality and speed), 'neural' (pure semantic search using embeddings), 'fast' (quick results with streamlined algorithms), 'deep' (comprehensive research mode with query expansion and detailed context)
parameters.note: 与 type 参数功能相同

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of search algorithm to use. 'neural' uses an embeddings-based model for semantic understanding, 'auto' (default) intelligently combines neural and other search methods for balanced results, 'fast' uses streamlined versions for quick responses, and 'deep' provides comprehensive search with query expansion and detailed context for thorough research
parameters.note: 与 searchType 参数功能相同

parameters.name: includeDomains
parameters.description: Whitelist of domains to search (without https:// or paths). Only results from these domains will be returned
parameters.note: 域名不需要包含 https:// 或路径

parameters.name: excludeDomains
parameters.description: Blacklist of domains to exclude from results. Use to filter out low-quality or irrelevant sources
parameters.note: 域名不需要包含 https:// 或路径

parameters.name: startPublishedDate
parameters.description: Include only content published on or after this date
parameters.note: 必须使用 ISO 8601 格式 (YYYY-MM-DD 或 YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.sssZ)

parameters.name: endPublishedDate
parameters.description: Include only content published on or before this date
parameters.note: 必须使用 ISO 8601 格式 (YYYY-MM-DD 或 YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.sssZ)

tools.name: company_search
tools.description: Search for companies, organizations, and businesses using search api. Optimized for finding company profiles including LinkedIn company pages, corporate websites, startup information, business details, and organizational data. Ideal for market research, competitor analysis, business development, investment research, and finding potential clients or partners. Use this tool when looking for: startups, enterprises, corporations, organizations, employers, tech companies, SaaS businesses, Fortune 500 companies, unicorns, or any type of business entity.

parameters.name: query
parameters.description: Natural language query to find companies and organizations. Be specific about industry, location, size, funding stage, or business model
examples: AI startups in Silicon Valley with Series A funding
B2B SaaS companies focused on HR tech
Cloud infrastructure startups backed by top VCs
Enterprise software companies with remote-first culture

parameters.name: numResults
parameters.description: Number of companies to return. Default: 5, Max: 10
parameters.note: 代码执行时会被限制为最大 10

parameters.name: searchType
parameters.description: Search algorithm mode for company search: 'auto' (default) - Intelligently combines neural and other search methods for balanced quality and speed, 'neural' - Pure semantic search using embeddings, good for understanding business models and company descriptions, 'fast' - Quick results with streamlined algorithms, suitable for simple queries, 'deep' - Most comprehensive search with query expansion, finds similar companies with different descriptions

tools.name: people_search
tools.description: Search for professionals, candidates, and individuals using search api. Optimized for finding people profiles including LinkedIn pages, professional backgrounds, resumes, CVs, and personal career information. Ideal for recruitment, talent sourcing, networking, and finding experts in specific fields. Use this tool when looking for: engineers, developers, sales professionals, executives, managers, researchers, scientists, designers, consultants, job candidates, industry experts, or any other type of professional.

parameters.name: query
parameters.description: Natural language query to find professionals. Be specific about role, skills, experience, location, or company
examples: senior backend engineers with Golang experience in San Francisco
product managers with B2B SaaS background
data scientists with PhD and publications in NLP
engineering managers who worked at FAANG companies
frontend developers specialized in React and TypeScript
sales directors with enterprise software experience
machine learning researchers at top AI labs
UX designers with healthcare product experience

parameters.name: numResults
parameters.description: Number of profiles to return. Default: 5, Max: 10
parameters.note: 代码执行时会被限制为最大 10

parameters.name: searchType
parameters.description: Search algorithm mode for people search: 'auto' (default) - Intelligently combines neural and other search methods for balanced quality and speed, 'neural' - Pure semantic search using embeddings, good for understanding complex professional profiles and skills, 'fast' - Quick results with streamlined algorithms, suitable for simple queries, 'deep' - Most comprehensive search with query expansion, finds similar profiles with different wordings

tools.name: clarify_question
tools.description:
Use this tool when user's question is unclear, missing necessary information, or has multiple possible interpretations.

Guidelines:
- **Prefer selections over text input**: Always use radio/checkbox when options are predictable (even if there are many possibilities, pick the most common 3-4)
- **Prioritize ruthlessly**: Only ask 1-3 questions that significantly impact the outcome
- **Sort by impact**: Order questions by how much they affect the final result (highest impact first)
- **Limit choices**: For radio/checkbox fields, provide ≤ 3 specific options + 1 generic fallback (e.g., "Other"/"Custom")
- Use text/textarea ONLY when:
  - User needs to provide unique identifiers (names, URLs, IDs)
  - Input is truly unpredictable and cannot be categorized
  - Free-form creative input is essential
- Provide clear description to help user understand each question
- Required fields should only be for truly critical information

parameters.name: title
parameters.description: Form title, briefly describe what needs clarification

parameters.name: description
parameters.description: Form description, explain why this information is needed
examples: To provide you with the most accurate help, please answer the following questions
We need a few details to proceed with your request

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description: List of form fields (top 1-3 most critical questions only). Each field object contains: id (string, required) - Unique field identifier; type (enum, required) - Field type: 'radio' for single selection, 'checkbox' for multiple selection, 'text'/'textarea'/'number'/'date' for input fields; label (string, required) - Field label; placeholder (string, optional) - Input placeholder text; description (string, optional) - Field description to help user understand the question; required (boolean, optional, default: true) - Whether the field is required; options (array, optional, max 4, required for radio/checkbox) - Options list with value and label, should provide ≤ 3 specific options + 1 generic option like 'Other'/'Custom'; defaultValue (string|number|boolean|string[], optional) - Default value; validation (object, optional) - Validation rules with min, max, pattern, and message properties

examples.label: Project Type
examples.description: Please select the type of project you want to create

examples.label: Required Features
examples.description: Select the features you need (multiple selection allowed)

validation.message: Project name can only contain letters, numbers, hyphens and underscores, 2-50 characters

examples.label: Website URL
examples.description: Enter the website address to analyze

examples.label: Project Description
examples.placeholder: Please describe your project requirements in detail...
examples.description: Describe your project requirements as detailed as possible

parameters.note: Field type should prioritize radio/checkbox over text/textarea for better UX. Options array is required for radio/checkbox types and should have maximum 4 items (≤ 3 specific options + 1 generic fallback). Use text/textarea only when user needs to provide unique identifiers, input is truly unpredictable, or free-form creative input is essential.

tools.name: confirm
tools.description:
Ask user for confirmation before executing dangerous operations.
Use when: deleting files, running destructive shell commands, modifying system configs, or any irreversible action.

parameters.name: message
parameters.description: Description of the dangerous action and its potential impact.
examples: This will permanently delete all files in the /tmp directory. This action cannot be undone.
This command will modify system configuration files and may affect system stability. Please confirm to proceed.
This operation will overwrite the existing database. All current data will be lost. Are you sure you want to continue?
Running this script will execute destructive shell commands that may delete important files. Proceed with caution.

tools.name: write_todos
tools.description: Update the todo list for the current session. To be used proactively and often to track progress and pending tasks. Make sure that at least one task is in_progress at all times.

parameters.name: todos
parameters.description: Array of todo items to create or update. Each todo item contains: content (string, required, min length: 1) - The task description or content; status (enum, required) - Current status of the task, must be one of: 'pending', 'in_progress', 'completed'; id (string, required, min length: 1) - Unique identifier for the task
parameters.note: Ensure at least one task has status 'in_progress' at all times to track active work

tools.name: complete
tools.description:
Use this tool to deliver file-based artifacts to the user with structured tracking.

IMPORTANT WORKFLOW:
1. First, you MUST use the 'write_file' tool to create or update the files
2. Verify the file content is correct and complete
3. Only then use this tool to deliver the artifacts

ARTIFACT TYPES:
- text: Text files (.md, .txt)
- pdf: PDF documents (.pdf)
- image: Image files (.jpg, .jpeg, .png, .gif, .webp, .svg, .bmp, .ico)
- document: Office documents (.doc, .docx)
- spreadsheet: Spreadsheet files (.xls, .xlsx, .csv)
- presentation: Presentation files (.ppt, .pptx)
- code: Code files (.py, .js, .jsx, .ts, .tsx, .html, .css)
- other: Other file types not covered above

This tool will:
- Deliver a set of artifacts (files) to the user
- Provide structured delivery summary and tracking
- Categorize artifacts by type for better organization

Do NOT use this tool before creating the files with write_file.

parameters.name: summary
parameters.description: Summary of what was delivered overall.
examples: Delivered a complete React application with authentication and user dashboard
Created documentation files including API reference and user guide
Generated three code files: main component, utilities, and configuration

parameters.name: artifacts
parameters.description: Array of artifacts to deliver. Each artifact object contains: type (enum, required) - The category of artifact being delivered, choose based on file extensions: text (.md, .txt), pdf (.pdf), image (.jpg, .png, .gif, etc.), document (.doc, .docx), spreadsheet (.xls, .xlsx, .csv), presentation (.ppt, .pptx), code (.py, .js, .jsx, .ts, .tsx, .html, .css), or other; path (string, required) - The absolute path to the file to deliver
parameters.note: Must use 'write_file' tool first to create or update files before delivering them with this tool. Artifact type should match the file extension: text (.md, .txt), pdf (.pdf), image (.jpg, .jpeg, .png, .gif, .webp, .svg, .bmp, .ico), document (.doc, .docx), spreadsheet (.xls, .xlsx, .csv), presentation (.ppt, .pptx), code (.py, .js, .jsx, .ts, .tsx, .html, .css), or other for unknown types.

tools.name: sb_file_create
tools.description: Create a new file with the provided contents at a given path in the workspace. The path must be relative to /workspace (e.g., "src/main.py" for /workspace/src/main.py).

parameters.name: filePath
parameters.description: Path to the file to be created, relative to /workspace
parameters.note: Path must be relative to /workspace. Parent directories will be created automatically if they don't exist. If the file already exists, use sb_file_edit to modify it or sb_file_rewrite to replace it.

parameters.name: fileContents
parameters.description: The content to write to the file. Limit each file to 15000 tokens maximum
examples:
# Project Documentation

This project is a web application built with Next.js.
parameters.note: Maximum file size is 15000 tokens. The tool will automatically create parent directories if needed.

tools.name: sb_file_rewrite
tools.description: Completely rewrite an existing file with new content. The file path must be relative to /workspace. IMPORTANT: Always prefer using edit_file for making changes to code. Only use this tool when edit_file fails or when you need to replace the entire file content.

parameters.name: filePath
parameters.description: Path to the file to be rewritten, relative to /workspace
parameters.note: Path must be relative to /workspace. The file must already exist. Use sb_file_create to create a new file if it doesn't exist.

parameters.name: fileContents
parameters.description: The new content to write to the file, replacing all existing content
examples:
# Updated Project Documentation

This project has been completely rewritten with new architecture.
parameters.note: This will completely replace all existing content in the file. Use with caution. Always prefer using edit_file for making changes to code.

tools.name: sb_file_delete
tools.description: Delete a file at the given path. The path must be relative to /workspace.

parameters.name: filePath
parameters.description: Path to the file to be deleted, relative to /workspace
parameters.note: Path must be relative to /workspace. The file must exist. This operation is irreversible - the file will be permanently deleted.

tools.name: sb_file_edit
tools.description:
Use this tool to make an edit to an existing file. This will be read by a less intelligent model, which will quickly apply the edit.
You should make it clear what the edit is, while also minimizing the unchanged code you write.
When writing the edit, you should specify each edit in sequence, with the special comment
// ... existing code ... to represent unchanged code in between edited lines.

For example:
// ... existing code ...
FIRST_EDIT
// ... existing code ...
SECOND_EDIT
// ... existing code ...
THIRD_EDIT
// ... existing code ...

You should still bias towards repeating as few lines of the original file as possible to convey the change.
But, each edit should contain sufficient context of unchanged lines around the code you're editing to resolve ambiguity.
DO NOT omit spans of pre-existing code (or comments) without using the // ... existing code ... comment to indicate its absence.
If you omit the existing code comment, the model may inadvertently delete these lines.
If you plan on deleting a section, you must provide context before and after to delete it.
Make sure it is clear what the edit should be, and where it should be applied.
ALWAYS make all edits to a file in a single edit_file instead of multiple edit_file calls to the same file.

parameters.name: targetFile
parameters.description: The target file to modify
parameters.note: Path must be relative to /workspace. The file must already exist.

parameters.name: instructions
parameters.description: A single sentence written in the first person describing what you're changing. Used to help disambiguate uncertainty in the edit.
examples: I'm adding a new prop 'disabled' to the Button component
I'm updating the error handling logic to catch network errors
I'm removing the deprecated function and replacing it with the new implementation
I'm adding a new route handler for POST requests

parameters.name: codeEdit
parameters.description: Specify ONLY the precise lines of code that you wish to edit. Use // ... existing code ... for unchanged sections.
parameters.note: Use // ... existing code ... to represent unchanged code sections. Each edit should contain sufficient context around the code you're editing to resolve ambiguity. DO NOT omit spans of pre-existing code without using the // ... existing code ... comment. Always make all edits to a file in a single edit_file call instead of multiple calls.

tools.name: sb_command_execute
tools.description:
Execute a shell command in the workspace directory.

IMPORTANT: 
- Commands are non-blocking by default and run in a tmux session.
- Working directory is automatically determined:
  * If command contains "sessions/{currentSessionId}/" or other workspace dirs (projects/tasks/memory/skills) → runs in /workspace
  * If command uses relative path like "file.py" OR "sessions/file.py" → runs in /workspace/sessions/{currentSessionId}
  * Use 'folder' parameter for explicit directory control (highest priority)
- File isolation: All session files are automatically stored in /workspace/sessions/{sessionId}/
- This is ideal for long-running operations like starting servers or build processes.
- Uses tmux sessions to maintain state between commands.
- This tool is essential for running CLI tools, installing packages, and managing system operations.

parameters.name: command
parameters.description: The shell command to execute. Use this for running CLI tools, installing packages, or system operations. Commands can be chained using &&, ||, and | operators.
examples: git status || echo 'Not a git repository'

parameters.name: folder
parameters.description: Optional relative path to a subdirectory of /workspace where the command should be executed. Example: "data/pdfs"
parameters.note: Has highest priority for determining working directory. If not provided, working directory is automatically determined based on command content.

parameters.name: sessionName
parameters.description: Optional name of the tmux session to use. Use named sessions for related commands that need to maintain state. Defaults to a random session name.
parameters.note: Use named sessions when you need to run multiple related commands that share state or when you want to check output later with sb_command_logs_get

parameters.name: blocking
parameters.description: Whether to wait for the command to complete. Defaults to false for non-blocking execution.
parameters.note: Set to true to wait for command completion. Useful for quick commands. For long-running operations, keep false and use sb_command_logs_get to check progress.

parameters.name: timeout
parameters.description: Optional timeout in seconds for blocking commands. Defaults to 60. Ignored for non-blocking commands.
parameters.note: Only applies when blocking is true. Maximum wait time for command to complete.

tools.name: sb_command_logs_get
tools.description: Check the output of a previously executed command in a tmux session. Use this to monitor the progress or results of non-blocking commands.

parameters.name: sessionName
parameters.description: The name of the tmux session to check.
parameters.note: Use the session name from sb_command_execute or sb_command_running_list to check output of a running command

parameters.name: killSession
parameters.description: Whether to terminate the tmux session after checking. Set to true when you're done with the command.
parameters.note: Set to true to clean up the session after checking output. Use this when the command has completed and you no longer need the session.

tools.name: sb_command_terminate
tools.description: Terminate a running command by killing its tmux session.

parameters.name: sessionName
parameters.description: The name of the tmux session to terminate.
parameters.note: Use the session name from sb_command_execute or sb_command_running_list to terminate a running command

tools.name: sb_command_running_list
tools.description: List all running tmux sessions and their status.
